image.altText: A group of soldiers in a vehicle

items.synopsis: For weeks, the objectives of Israel's ground assault in Gaza have remained obscured by a veil of secrecy. But as tanks push further and further into the coastal enclave, a plan is starting to take shape.

title.children: Israel's war strategy in Gaza is slowly emerging. It's unlike anything they've done there before

image.altText: Israeli tanks manoeuvre inside the Gaza Strip, as seen from Israel,

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says Israel will press ahead with its plans to wipe out Hamas as Israeli troops and tanks attack Gaza's main northern city from the east and west.

title.children: Netanyahu rejects calls for ceasefire as Israeli tanks attack Gaza City

image.altText: A bell at a memorial garden.

items.synopsis: The RSL is pleading for the return of a memorial bell which dates back to the 19th century, and was stolen from a monument for veterans north-east of Adelaide.

title.children: Bell stolen from SA war memorial an act of 'desecration' ahead of Remembrance Day

image.altText: CCTV image shows three people on the floor and a person on a phone.

items.synopsis: The family of an Aboriginal man who died after an incident involving two security guards says new allegations of violence in the industry show lessons have not been learnt.

title.children: This man yelled 'I can't breathe' before he died. There was no global outcry

image.altText: Two firefigthers at truck

items.synopsis: After two days of cooler temperatures, firefighters in south-western Queensland are on high alert today, with hot weather and strong winds expected to make for dangerous fire conditions. Follow live.

title.children: More than 50 homes lost as Queensland braces for 'extremely savage day'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's Mr Albanese: "Today we will have established a recovery center center in Tara. "We expect some 42,000 claims as a result of these fires so far. "[Emergency] Minister Murray Watt is visiting that area today to see what other support can be offered. I spoke to David Democrat the local member yesterday and offered my support. "Victorian and New Zealand crews will soon be on the ground there to help. These are heartbreaking scenes when people lose their their houses."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Heartbreaking scenes': Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is speaking about the fire response

children.content: Here's Mr Albanese:
"Today we will have established a recovery center center in Tara.
"We expect some 42,000 claims as a result of these fires so far.
"[Emergency] Minister Murray Watt is visiting that area today to see what other support can be offered.
I spoke to David Democrat the local member yesterday and offered my support.
"Victorian and New Zealand crews will soon be on the ground there to help. These are heartbreaking scenes when people lose their their houses."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We were hearing overnight that 46 homes had been lost, but that has now been updated to 53, Western Downs Mayor Paul McVeigh confirmed on ABC News. "So very, very tough situation and we haven't ascertained all the damage as yet. Some of the areas the just too hot to get into. We are expecting that those numbers will increase and which is a really savage blow to the owners of those residents and certainly to our community. "Can I say a very big thank you to our whole community, how our community has rallied behind and in support of those who have been victims of this fire, it's been incredible. "And hopefully some of the meetings we're having today, we're out in Tara to try to support our community, let them know where some of that support can come from as well."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Savage' news that 53 homes have been lost on the Western Downs

children.content: We were hearing overnight that 46 homes had been lost, but that has now been updated to 53,
Western Downs Mayor Paul McVeigh
confirmed on ABC News.

"So very, very tough situation and we haven't ascertained all the damage as yet. Some of the areas the just too hot to get into. We are expecting that those numbers will increase and which is a really savage blow to the owners of those residents and certainly to our community.
"Can I say a very big thank you to our whole community, how our community has rallied behind and in support of those who have been victims of this fire, it's been incredible.
"And hopefully some of the meetings we're having today, we're out in Tara to try to support our community, let them know where some of that support can come from as well."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Residents of properties between Wieambilla Road, Chinchilla Tara Road, Upper Humbug Road, Drildool Road, Joseph Street and Clynes/Weitzels Road have been told to LEAVE IMMEDIATELY. QFES says: "There are multiple dangerous fires burning in the area." "QFES has used Emergency Alert text and voice message to warn people in the affected area about this fire."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Emergency warning: Tara, Montrose North, Wieambilla and The Gums

children.content: Residents of properties between Wieambilla Road, Chinchilla Tara Road, Upper Humbug Road, Drildool Road, Joseph Street and Clynes/Weitzels Road have been told to
LEAVE IMMEDIATELY
QFES says: "There are multiple dangerous fires burning in the area."
"QFES has used Emergency Alert text and voice message to warn people in the affected area about this fire."

title.children: Why rooftop solar is so crucial for Australia's renewable targets

title.children: Former Q+A host Stan Grant seemingly takes aim at Jacinta Nampijinpa Price in referendum reflections

items.synopsis: Actor Matthew Perry's co-stars from the iconic sitcom Friends pay tribute to the late actor in a statement to People.

title.children: Matthew Perry's Friends co-stars pay tribute to the late actor

image.altText: Still featuring Leonardo DiCaprio, Lily Gladstone and Robert De niro

items.synopsis: Studios have cracked down on a handful of overseas cinemas for running Killers of the Flower Moon with an interval, but the head of two dozen cinemas in Australia says customers should be given a choice.

title.children: 'It's about choice': Cinema CEO blasts studios over no interval for Killers of the Flower Moon

image.altText: A person wearing a bike helmet standing at an empty bank counter

items.synopsis: Kym Parsons's lawyer says his client had lost 7 kilograms in custody, and argues that denying bail would condemn him to death without a trial.

title.children: Terminally ill alleged 'bicycle bandit' to be released on bail

image.altText: warehouse with exposed beams under roof and solar panels on the ground in Bringelly

items.synopsis: Strong winds cause power outages to homes and businesses across Sydney's western and south-western suburbs as emergency crews are called to hundreds of clean up jobs.

title.children: Thousands of homes without power, trees down as strong winds hit Sydney amid extreme fire danger

image.altText: A sign saying "Australian Government Department of Home Affairs" outside a tall building. There are leaves in the foreground

items.synopsis: Australia's 888 visa system that has granted 26,000 "golden visas' to the super rich is out of step with the rest of the world, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: The super rich have a golden ticket to Australia — but what is it costing?

image.altText: A bald middle aged white man. He's sitting in a wheelchair and wearing a blue sweater

items.synopsis: A Victorian man is taking his fight to become an NDIS participant to the UN, accusing the Australian government of age discrimination and breaching his human rights.

title.children: NDIS access would change Peter's life, but he's locked out and says the reason is 'cruel and unfair'

image.altText: Chinese President Xi Jinping talks to Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands in a 2019 meeting.

items.synopsis: A leading think tank is warning the Australian government to be careful not to overload Pacific countries with debt in China's absence.

title.children: Researchers say the Pacific has 'woken up' to Chinese investment: Where does that leave Australia?

image.altText: A pictorial representation of Australian GDP sitting on the edge of a cliff.

items.synopsis: Like Looney Tunes' famous cartoon villain, the Reserve Bank risks running Australia's economy over a cliff if it becomes too single-minded in its pursuit of the inflation Road Runner, writes Michael Janda.

title.children: The Reserve Bank is trying to hammer inflation, but will it break the economy doing it?

image.altText: Maddy Zarb sitting in a wheelchair looking at the camera

items.synopsis: What was supposed to be a joyous trip to watch her beloved Blues in an AFL final turned to heartbreak for a teacher who is facing mounting costs.

title.children: 'Like they've broken one of my legs': Maddy's wheelchair was broken on a flight, it cost her nearly $8,000

image.altText: A soccer player wearing light blue holds her arms out and yells during a game

items.synopsis: After finishing third in voting in 2021 and 2022, Kerr finishes second this time around as the Ballon d'Or Féminin is awarded to Spain's Aitana Bonmatí.

title.children: Sam Kerr just misses out on top women's gong as Lionel Messi wins record eighth men's Ballon d'Or

image.altText: A human hand holds up a cane toad from the back legs to torch light at a dark Kimberley waterbody

items.synopsis: Scientists have dropped sausages made out of cane toads to deter vulnerable wildlife in the Kimberley from eating the pest. Unfortunately, the snags don't appear to be working, but there's another plan afoot to protect the Pilbara.

title.children: Air-dropped cane toad snags may not be the solution to extinctions Australia was hoping for

image.altText: Ana Kresina smiles for a portrait while holding her phone. She's sitting in front of a brick wall.

items.synopsis: Even though we were already parents, it wasn't easy to plan for the financial impact of a second child.

title.children: I couldn't find information on how to plan financially for parenthood, so I wrote a book

image.altText: A drawing of a dinosaur running through a dusty forest towards a dinosaur skeleton

items.synopsis: The asteroid 66 million years ago erased three-quarters of the world's species in an instant — but new research suggests the final blow may have unfolded in the following years, as the skies were darkened by clouds of debris and temperatures plunged.

title.children: How the asteroid that wiped out the dinosaurs may have sparked a climate catastrophe

image.altText: A small shark with black spots lays on the sea floor.

items.synopsis: A world-first shark 'rewilding' project is helping the endangered zebra shark, but it could also provide a template to help save other threatened marine species.

title.children: Sharks on a plane: An ambitious international project is helping save this endangered species

image.altText: A man wearing a blue and white button up shirt leans his elbow on a fence and looks out over the beach

items.synopsis: Seok Hee Lee grew up in Australia after immigrating from South Korea nearly two decades ago. When his mum applied for a visa, he was considered a dependent child. But after years of waiting for the application to be processed, Mr Lee's application was denied — because he is now an adult.

title.children: Lengthy parent visa processing times pose challenges for children

image.altText: A helicopter flies over a ship on open water.

items.synopsis: The Israel-Gaza war and Russia's invasion of Ukraine could become "strategic distractions" for the United States, a senior US military figure warns, saying a dangerous world creates circumstances that can strain resources.

title.children: Middle East and Ukraine conflicts risk causing 'strategic distraction' for US in Indo-Pacific

image.altText: A man looks at stock prices through the window of the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: A rally on Wall Street sends Australian stocks higher, while oil prices ease on lessening fears about the Israel-Gaza war disrupting supply from the region. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises after a broad-based rally on Wall Street, AustralianSuper rejects Brookfield offer

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Like Looney Tunes' famous cartoon villain, the Reserve Bank risks running Australia's economy over a cliff if it becomes too single-minded in its pursuit of the inflation Road Runner, writes Michael Janda.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is Australia's economy facing a Wile E Coyote moment?

featuredLink.title: The Reserve Bank is trying to hammer inflation, but will it break the economy doing it?

children.content: Like Looney Tunes' famous cartoon villain, the Reserve Bank risks running Australia's economy over a cliff if it becomes too single-minded in its pursuit of the inflation Road Runner, writes Michael Janda.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rental listings in Hobart are at their highest level in a decade, while nationally availability has hit a record low. The price of rentals has also dropped by 7.4 per cent, compared with a 14.6 per cent rise nationally. Despite the changes to Hobart's market, housing advocates say the city remains unaffordable for many. Read more from Clancy Balen.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hobart rental market bucks national trend

featuredLink.title: Hobart rental listings are at the highest level in a decade, as the city bucks the national trend

children.content: Rental listings in Hobart are at their highest level in a decade, while nationally availability has hit a record low.
The price of rentals has also dropped by 7.4 per cent, compared with a 14.6 per cent rise nationally.
Despite the changes to Hobart's market, housing advocates say the city remains unaffordable for many.
Read more from
Clancy Balen.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wall Street rallied on Monday, kicking off what promises to be a hectic week that includes a heavy earnings docket, economic data and the Federal Reserve's two-day monetary policy meeting. All three major US stock indexes closed up more than 1 per cent, bouncing back from the previous week's sell-off. Interest-rate-sensitive megacap stocks, led by Microsoft, Amazon, and Apple provided the most upside muscle. "Today is an earnings rebound," said Oliver Pursche, senior vice president at Wealthspire Advisors, in New York. "The market got oversold, and the reality is that earnings have been pretty good, the US economy continues to chug along, and is likely to do so in the fourth quarter and into the first part of next year." Third-quarter earnings season, firing on all cylinders, has reached its halfway point, with 251 of the companies in the S & P 500 having reported. Of those, 78 per cent have beaten Wall Street estimates, according to LSEG. Analysts now expect, on aggregate, annual third-quarter S & P 500 earnings growth of 4.3 per cent, a marked improvement over the 1.6 per cent year-on-year growth seen at the beginning of October. Investors have shown "less pessimism," Pursche added. "First- and second-quarter calls had a more negative tone. There was anxiety over interest rates, Fed policy, the recession that never came." In the coming week, Caterpillar, Apple, Pfizer and Starbucks are among the higher-profile companies expected to post results. On Tuesday, the Federal Open Markets Committee is expected to convene for a two-day monetary policy meeting, which is expected to culminate in a decision to let the Fed funds target rate stand at 5.25-5.50 per cent. Investors will scrutinize the accompanying statement and Fed chair Jerome Powell's subsequent Q & A session for clues regarding the central bank's path forward with rates. "The Fed wants to see the cumulative effects of their rate hikes on the economy but they've also said they're prepared to over-shoot in an abundance of caution, as long as inflation is above 3 per cent," Pursche said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wall Street bounces, powered by earnings momentum

children.content: Wall Street rallied on Monday, kicking off what promises to be a hectic week that includes a heavy earnings docket, economic data and the Federal Reserve's two-day monetary policy meeting.
All three major US stock indexes closed up more than 1 per cent, bouncing back from the previous
week's sell-off.
Interest-rate-sensitive megacap
stocks, led by Microsoft, Amazon, and Apple provided the most upside muscle.

"Today is an earnings rebound," said Oliver Pursche, senior vice president at Wealthspire Advisors, in New York. "The market got oversold, and the reality is that earnings have been pretty good, the US economy continues to chug along, and is likely to do so in the fourth quarter and into the first part of next year."
Third-quarter earnings season, firing on all cylinders, has reached its halfway point, with 251 of the companies in the S
P 500 having reported. Of those, 78 per cent have beaten Wall Street estimates, according to LSEG.
Analysts now expect, on aggregate, annual third-quarter S
P 500 earnings growth of 4.3 per cent, a marked improvement over the 1.6 per cent year-on-year growth seen at the beginning of October.
Investors have shown "less pessimism," Pursche added. "First- and second-quarter calls had a more negative tone. There was anxiety over interest rates, Fed policy, the recession that never came."
In the coming week, Caterpillar, Apple, Pfizer and Starbucks are among the higher-profile companies expected to post results.

On Tuesday, the Federal Open Markets Committee is expected to convene for a two-day monetary policy meeting, which is expected to culminate in a decision to let the Fed funds target rate stand at 5.25-5.50 per cent.
Investors will scrutinize the accompanying statement and Fed chair Jerome Powell's subsequent Q
A session for clues regarding the central bank's path forward with rates.

"The Fed wants to see the cumulative effects of their rate hikes on the economy but they've also said they're prepared to over-shoot in an abundance of caution, as long as inflation is above 3 per cent," Pursche said.
